titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding aid prepared by Brian Carpenter

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T21:14-0400

did.unittitle: Tuscarora Material
did.abstract: Recorded by Anthony Wallace in 1948 and 1949 at the Tuscarora Reservation in Niagara County, New York. Contains folkloric stories, tribal histories (especially relating to the 18th and 19th centuries), autobiographical stories, reminiscences, word lists, and descriptions of tribal government, organizations, and customs. Almost all stories are given in both Tuscarora and English. Originally recorded on 16 wire spools, transfered to open reel tape in 1950.
did.physdesc: 30 open reel tapes (14 hr., 38 min.) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: A transcript of the majority of the recordings can be found in the Franz Boas Collection of Materials for American Linguistics collection (Mss.497.3.B63c). Related material, including photographs of the recordings sessions, can be found in the Anthony Wallace papers (Mss.497.3.Am4).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Anthony Wallace in 1950. This material was recorded with the assistance of a Phillips Fund grant.

accessrestrict.head: Note on Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Access to recordings of Thematic Apperception Tests or Rorschach tests is restricted.

did.unittitle: Ottawa speech

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of short clips of Ottawa speech by an unidentified female speaker. These clips are found in between other recordings on the original wire recording. Wire was first used by Jane Willets in recording Ottawa in Michigan in 1947. This wire was later re-used by Anthony Wallace for recordings of Tuscarora in New York state.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: This file is a compressed, digitized version of the original. The APS Library maintains the original format (Wire recording) as well as an uncompressed digitized version of this recording.

did.unittitle: The story of the boy who abused the false face

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Re-telling of "The little folk and the little boy who played with them in the woods" told by Dan Smith. (See Related Recording.) Continuation of story begun of beginning of wire 2. The first 2-feet of the wire on this spool was discarded by the collector due to tangling.

did.unittitle: A Story about General Peter A. Porter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The General identified on the recording as Peter A. Porter is actually Peter Buell Porter. At time of recording, the speaker was Grand President of the Indian Defense League of America.

did.unittitle: How some Tuscaroras migrated to Kansas

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "[Kansas migration in 1840s. Rickard's grandpa was there.] [Time of Mexican war.] [About 1840 my grandpa was young man, died 94.]" At time of recording, the speaker was Grand President of the Indian Defense League of America.

did.unittitle: The present Tuscarora terms for the Tuscarora words included in the Jefferson manuscript vocabulary in the American Philosophical Society Library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At time of recording, the speaker, (Chief) William "Willy-hah" Mountpleasant carried the title of Head Sachem of the Tuscaroras, and had been Secretary to the Chief's Council for 16 years.

did.unittitle: The man who came with the message of peace

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This story is a version of the legend of Deganawida, or the Great Peacemaker, one of the traditional founders of the Haudenosaunee (or Iroquois) Confederacy.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: This file is a compressed, digitized version of the original. The APS Library maintains the original format (Wire recording) as well as an uncompressed digitized version of this recording.

did.unittitle: The Devil's Story

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "General outline of story: man bet devil his heart/soul he cd build a house by dawn (cock-crow). He was able to do so, and save his soul, but the devil in anger tore down the house." Wire became tangled during recording, causing part of the story to be lost.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note

did.unittitle: The dispute over the Canadian Indians

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerns Iroquois Indians living in Canada and a disupte regarding their rights under the Jay Treaty of 1794 to cross the border freely.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: This file is a compressed, digitized version of the original. The APS Library maintains the original format (Wire recording) as well as an uncompressed digitized version of this recording.
